# 2.5
```{r}
data(iris)
# ?iris
# iris
summary(iris)
attach(iris) # Makes the columns accessible as variable names from within the R, also didn't know this

species.n <- as.numeric(Species)

plot(iris, col = species.n)

hist(Petal.Length)

op <- par(mfrow = c(2,2))

for (i in 1:4) {
  boxplot(iris[,i]~Species, main = colnames(iris)[i])
}

par(op)

#############
library(rpart)

(rpo <- rpart(Species~.,
              data = iris))
plot(rpo, margin = 0.1,
     branch = 0.5)
text(rpo)

#############
library(MASS)

(ldao <- lda(Species~.,
             data = iris))
plot(ldao, abbrev = TRUE,
     col = species.n)

#############
detach(iris)
ls() # check if detached
```

# 2.7
```{r}
4 < 3
(3+1) != 3
# -3<-2 # R thinks this is an arrow <- and assignment
-3 < -2

#############

(3 >= 2) && (4 == (3 + 1))
FALSE && TRUE
TRUE && FALSE
TRUE || FALSE
x <- 0
TRUE || (x <- 3) # the second expression is not evaluated, the algorithm stops at first TRUE
x

FALSE || TRUE
FALSE || (x <- 3) # the second expression IS evaluated, because the first argument was FALSE
x # therefore it is changed

#############

c(TRUE, TRUE) & c(FALSE, FALSE) # one & works vector-wise: the first of first vector is compared with the first of second vector
c(TRUE, TRUE) && c(TRUE, TRUE) # two && do not evaluate vector-wise, and return just one value

#############

T & F
T & T
T <- 0 # TRUE <- 0 doesn't work though, because it is a reserved word in R
T & T

T <- 1

#############

sum(FALSE, TRUE, TRUE)

x <- c(-3, 5, 2, 0, -2)
x < 0 # works vector-wise
sum(x < 0) # can provide information about how many members fulfill condition

#############

x <- c(2, 9, 3, 1, 6)
eininge <- x > 4
alle <- x > 0

any(eininge)
any(alle)
any(!alle) # inverses vector
all(eininge)
all(alle)
which(eininge) # which are true
which.max(x)

#############
x <- NA
str(NA)
y <- c(3, x)
str(y) # vector-wise

#############

x <- c(NA, 7, NA, 22)
mean(x) # NA is "contagious"
mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)
na.omit(x)

attr(na.omit(x),"na.action") # writes the positions where NAs were removed and what happened to them. This is actually really cool
```
